input: Absolutely! Have you ever watched a loved one in the final stages of incurable cancer writhe in pain, babble incoherently, emit blood curdling screams? Have you seen a vibrant, capable man overcome by ALS wither into a useless body, shutting themselves, wanting to die, but being denied that dignity? Do you think Tesslyn O'Cull's life was worth living? Should Jesse Compton be given room and board and another breath? Speaking for me, my life involves using my body and my brain to take care of myself and enjoy the pleasures and even the trials that I've earned. If I am injured to the point of permanent incapacitation or am stricken with an incurable illness, I'm outta here. That's not "life" to me.

Obviously, the stakes in November's election have just risen.  We can be guaranteed that the GOP controlled Senate will block any Obama nomination.  Therefore, one of the first duties on a newly elected President will be to select a new Supreme Court Justice.  One of the first duties of a newly elected Senate will be to consider that nomination and approve or reject it.  The importance of control of the Senate has just spiked up several notches.

Releasing any invasive species into the wild is foolish.  Releasing an invasive predator is even worse.  Its prey have no natural defenses and are unaware of their habits.  This puts them at an extreme disadvantage in the food chain.  As mentioned before, cats don't just hunt to survive, they also hunt for sport.  I've had to deal with feral cats on a couple of occasions.  Like any wild animal, they are viscous, territorial and dangerous.  Feral cats aren't the same as your average house cat.  Yes, they are the same species but they're a completely different animal.  I would prefer not to have to kill them, but like Old Yeller, some times what must be done, must be done.

I challenge anyone to propose a reasonable alternative to eradication.  I know of none since these cats have no real natural habitat.  TNR is not a reasonable solution for any invasive species.  It devastates an entire ecosystem just to protect a handful of cats.  It should remain illegal.

Wolves in the wild typically only live between 6 and 8 years. If these wolves are 10, then they are really decrepit old senior citizens at this point. And once they get habituated to killing livestock, they will not stop. They will just keep coming back time and time again, just as these wolves did.

Think of this as being more of an act of euthanasia. It is really showing kindness to them, to relieve them from the stress and misery of old age, and all of its pains and disabilities.   They have lived long and good lives, and eaten plenty of meat.   Let them move on to wolf heaven.  It is their proper time.

Bruce: Thank you for your letter, it offers the most valuable perspective I can imagine.  I'm 73 and have recently witnessed the very "difficult" deaths of two good friends...One from ALS, the other after a long, "losing" battle with cancer.  Both men reached the point where they were in constant pain, needed heavy, heavy pain medication and had no "in between" time giving them any quality of life....either intense pain or drug-induced "sleep."

I strongly agree with you.  At some point, it's time to "wave the white flag" and end one's life.  It should be, as you say, at the stage of your choosing.  

It's a difficult circumstance, a difficult choice and a difficult topic for discussion.  Thank you for reminding us all that we need to consider it, and, perhaps, will face the choice ourselves.  We need the legal authority to do so.

my best to you,  Gary

From their own website:  The 1976 state law establishing the Permanent Fund (AS 37.13), states that the Fund was created:
to provide a means of conserving a portion of the state's revenue from mineral resources to benefit all generations of Alaskans
to maintain safety of principal while maximizing total return
to be a savings device managed to allow maximum use of disposable income for purposes designated by law.

I think that's pretty clear insofar as it's purpose.    To conserve for the benefit of all generations of Alaskans.    Using the principal to produce earning to fund government (like Norway did for example) is certainly one way the fund, using a POMV payment model, would provide benefit to all generations of Alaskan's, not just the individuals who happen to live in Alaska for a year, then get a dividend that second year.

He was far from perfect.  Too much militarism, too cozy with big business and all that.  But given the congress he had to deal with he made more progress can I expected.  And just think if he had lost either election.

From january of this year: "National Rifle Association’s (NRA) New York state financial disclosure forms for 2014 are now online, and like past years’ tax filings, the documents provide a rare glimpse at the organization’s inner machinery. The group’s total revenues fell from more than $347 million in 2013 to roughly $310 million. Contributing to the decline was a drop in income collected from its members. Revenue from annual dues fell from $175 million to $128 million in 2014, a drop of 27 percent."

Uh, yeah you do *if* someone is threatening harm to you and/or family. Tallman assaulted Larson several times with the intent to harm. Tallman's intentions were obviously not good ones and Larson acted within his rights to self-preservation to defend himself on his own property.  Larson does not seem the type to fit your so-called definition of a person "just looking for a reason to run around blasting away..." but he does sound like someone who was merciful in only wounding Tallman, not giving him a fatal shot.  There is no handgun epidemic -- guns are not an epidemic on their own. It's specific (often dumb) *people* using handguns that are the epidemic -- those often not registering their firearms, aren't trained, and often, running around only with violent intentions, not for reasons of self-defense.

Automation has been in use in Europe for years...long before our debate about $15 hr...never been able to figure out why they get tech long before we do.
They were using card chips long before us also...in a completely different way...waiter comes to table with wireless scanner, scans card and immediately hands it back...completely opposite of our use of the chip, where we put card in, complete transaction , take card out. Leave it up to us to screw that up too.
Back to the point - lol - at McD's across euro, enter order at kiosk, get receipt number, pick up at counter. Talk about efficient. Hey, did I mention how much better euro Big Macs taste than ours? Ok, I guess I've digressed enough :)

Historically, Oregon legislators and State officials have had as much interest in quality higher education as they have had in Saturn. Their interest has been in how to get degrees to as many students as possible in as short a time as possible for as little expense as possible. Their euphemism for degrading education is "removing obstacles to graduation." I wouldn't count on them for holding anyone accountable for anything but spending less.

The UO, like many universities, has to cater to a customer base that includes out of state and international students in order for it to stay in business. How far this catering goes depends on "enrollment management" needs. EM is quite a complicated part of the forecasting business for hitting targets. These customers require marketing strategies and retention efforts against competition from other U's.

Given the pressures and limits, faculty at the UO generally do a courageous and effective job of preserving educational quality.

The problem with the editorial and your comment is that it is myopic.  There is much more enterprise in the local economy than just software.  Even in software, there has been activity for decades with game companies and educational software employing up to hundreds back to the early nineties.  But beyond the tiny software industry tens of thousands are employed in other lines of work and new companies are starting all the time but without incubators or fan fare.  Software jockey's tend to think highly of themselves, but those of use who have started high tech manufacturing companies and such see the focus to be a bit misplaced.  The overall health of the local economy is dependent on a broad spectrum of activity far beyond software.  Software is a small and competitive industry.  Local focus should support the broader spectrum of new business including manufacturing, timber, medical, etc.

Answer you?  I'm trying to figure out what you're saying here:  Don't you think recycling is a little better than digging it up (or chopping it down) and throwing it in a landfill?  Yes, it takes effort, equipment, and infrastructure---I hope we as a  society are able to engage in a science-and-evidence-based discussion over whether the net result is really worth it.  

I've read studies that indicate we could possibly phase out fossil fuels in a decade:  I can see that as a possible motive for oil producers to flood the market and drive the price of their product down, and try to shift this discussion to the background for as long as possible, with the "help" of people like Sarah and you.

Civil Comments, one of the nice features that the Facebook commenting system had was the ability to screen out trolls that you didn't want to be bothered with, like this one-line-wonder.  It didn't eliminate their ability to comment, it just cleared the noise out of the comments that readers needed to wade through so they could focus on those comments that add real value or insight rather than comments from trolls like this one that only seek to antagonize rather then have dialogue. 

I often don't agree with commenters, but I usually appreciate their viewpoints.  But there are a few like this one who only detract from my participation in the comments. 

Please consider adding that valuable feature.  Thank you.

Begich is the worst person to be giving Gov. Walker advice.  As mayor of Anchorage Begich grew the Anchorage operating budget from $294 million in 2003 to $422 million when he left in 2009.

Vetoing the state budget results in all state employees being given lay off notices just weeks before the new fiscal year.  That would be divisive and stupid.

Begich also calls for new taxes and a raid on the Permanent Fund which are both recessionary.  Begich was missing in action when we were having a statewide debate on SB-21- which is mostly responsible for the massive deficits we have today.  But nowhere in this article does Begich mention the fiasco of how we give away almost $10 billion in oil per year for only the royalty payment due to SB-21.

Finally, Begich gave us the disaster that is ACA- and its crippling insurance costs.

Begich needs to go away.  He failed Alaska multiple times.

Just because you don't pay income taxes doesn't mean you don't work. It may just mean you work your ass off to make life comfortable for people like the author of this article. And it doesn't mean you don't pay ANY taxes, just not income taxes. I get so tired of that "makers and takers" line of b.s.. It's not that simple. You want a sales tax? Fine, let's do it this way; exempt the first $500. of every purchase and tax every $ after that instead of the other way around. Does that sound fair to you?

If we vote, instead, for those who are neither Republican or Democrat, who will we have left to vote for, and will those minor political parties be able to field candidates in all districts?  I don't know any other party that can do that.  The majority of voting Alaskans are registered as non-aligned/non-partisan/independent (choose your label).  But there is NO political party that sponsors this type of candidate.  Now, if enough people choose to rally around "anyone but D / R," perhaps we can see what a Legislature can do outside of the "mainstream" political system.  But, most importantly, we need to have those candidates on the ballot.  Where are they?

I appreciate your comment about there being possible factors that contributed to the accident which do not have anything to do with the pilot. We have been told by the NTSB that they will be investigating those areas. Those of us making comments only know the immediate outcome. As well as determining probable cause, if possible, the NTSB may also make safety recommendations. I read a briefing of one accident report which states that the NTSB had issued 34 safety recommendations and these were not limited to the actions of the pilots; one recommendation was to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Let's not prejudge (as in "prejudice"). Let's keep an open mind and hope for the best. We may be surprised.  There's a lot to criticize in this world. I do my share of it. But I see a lot of negative thinking in people's comments (I'm speaking generally here) sometimes with no other point than to nitpick and be negative. Some of that energy needs to be turned to positive, solution oriented thinking and actions. Otherwise, we're creating the very world we say we don't want.

There are many more reasons to transition off of dirty fossil fuels than global warming...global warming is the biggest reason, but fracking is using massive amounts of water and poisons it as well.  What need to be done is work on energy conservation. We should also stop subsidizing the fossil fuel industry- the wealthiest industry in history and the most devastating....
What's that old saying?  "If you're not taking flak, you're not over the target."  Well Mr. Ryan, I'd say in this case your target acquisition has been close to perfect.
I've always believed that political candidates can rack in the bucks, but in the end the voters have the only say.  Uninformed voters can be easily hoodwinked.
